headline: Redistricting commission prepares for debate over new congressional district map
author: Andy Chow
sentences: House Speaker Bob Cupp (R-Lima) said during a commission meeting Thursday that the commission could meet multiple times this week for public hearings and for possible proposals from legislative leaders.
of State Frank LaRose (R-Ohio), a member of the redistricting commission, has urged the other commissioners to act quickly in order for the state to have a primary May 3.
By a 4-3 decision, the court said the map gave Republicans an advantage and did not reflect Ohio's voter preference in proportion to the 15 congressional districts.
The commission is expected to make a move on a new congressional district map this week after completing work, for now, on updated state legislative maps.
Lawmakers extended the deadline to March 4 for congressional candidates to file their petitions to be on the primary ballot.
That map creates eight Republican districts, six Democratic districts, and one competitive district that leans Democratic.
That's 80% of the districts in a state that voted for former President Donald Trump with 53% of the vote in 2020.
The first attempt at a new congressional district map was found unconstitutional by the Ohio Supreme Court.
That map, drawn through SB258, created 12 seats that either heavily favor or lean in favor of Republicans.
Democratic leaders on the redistricting commission have introduced their own congressional district plan.
This is the first time the Ohio Redistricting Commission will adopt a congressional map.
Mike DeWine (R-Ohio) signed into law before the court invalidated the map.
